filteredMethods.formHtml:
Parameters

The beginning of the timespan for the data. The maximum lookback period is 31 days from today.

The timespan for which the information will be fetched. If specifying timespan, do not specify parameter t0. The value must be in seconds and be less than or equal to 31 days. The default is 1 day.
filteredMethods.summary: List the clients of a device up to a maximum of a month ago. The usage of each client is returned in kilobytes. If the device is a switch the switchport is returned; otherwise the switchport field is null.

filteredMethods.formHtml:
Parameters

The beginning of the timespan for the data. The maximum lookback period is 31 days from today.

The timespan for which the information will be fetched. If specifying timespan, do not specify parameter t0. The value must be in seconds and be less than or equal to 31 days. The default is 1 day.

The number of entries per page returned. Acceptable range is 3 - 1000. Default is 10.

A token used by the server to indicate the start of the page. Often this is a timestamp or an ID but it is not limited to those. This parameter should not be defined by client applications. The link for the first, last, prev, or next page in the HTTP Link header should define it.

A token used by the server to indicate the end of the page. Often this is a timestamp or an ID but it is not limited to those. This parameter should not be defined by client applications. The link for the first, last, prev, or next page in the HTTP Link header should define it.
filteredMethods.summary: List the clients that have used this network in the timespan

filteredMethods.formHtml: Parameters
filteredMethods.summary: Provisions a client with a name and policy. Clients can be provisioned before they associate to the network.

filteredMethods.summary: Return the client associated with the given identifier. Clients can be identified by a client key or either the MAC or IP depending on whether the network uses Track-by-IP.

filteredMethods.formHtml:
Parameters

The number of entries per page returned. Acceptable range is 3 - 100. Default is 100.

A token used by the server to indicate the start of the page. Often this is a timestamp or an ID but it is not limited to those. This parameter should not be defined by client applications. The link for the first, last, prev, or next page in the HTTP Link header should define it.

A token used by the server to indicate the end of the page. Often this is a timestamp or an ID but it is not limited to those. This parameter should not be defined by client applications. The link for the first, last, prev, or next page in the HTTP Link header should define it.
filteredMethods.summary: Return the events associated with this client. Clients can be identified by a client key or either the MAC or IP depending on whether the network uses Track-by-IP.

filteredMethods.formHtml:
Parameters

The beginning of the timespan for the data. The maximum lookback period is 791 days from today.

The end of the timespan for the data. t1 can be a maximum of 791 days after t0.

The timespan for which the information will be fetched. If specifying timespan, do not specify parameters t0 and t1. The value must be in seconds and be less than or equal to 791 days. The default is 1 day.

The time resolution in seconds for returned data. The valid resolutions are: 86400. The default is 86400.
filteredMethods.summary: Return the latency history for a client. Clients can be identified by a client key or either the MAC or IP depending on whether the network uses Track-by-IP. The latency data is from a sample of 2% of packets and is grouped into 4 traffic categories: background best effort video voice. Within these categories the sampled packet counters are bucketed by latency in milliseconds.

filteredMethods.formHtml: Parameters
filteredMethods.summary: Return the policy assigned to a client on the network. Clients can be identified by a client key or either the MAC or IP depending on whether the network uses Track-by-IP.

filteredMethods.formHtml: Parameters
filteredMethods.summary: Update the policy assigned to a client on the network. Clients can be identified by a client key or either the MAC or IP depending on whether the network uses Track-by-IP.

filteredMethods.formHtml: Parameters
filteredMethods.summary: Return the splash authorization for a client for each SSID theyve associated with through splash. Clients can be identified by a client key or either the MAC or IP depending on whether the network uses Track-by-IP.

filteredMethods.summary: Update a clients splash authorization. Clients can be identified by a client key or either the MAC or IP depending on whether the network uses Track-by-IP.

filteredMethods.formHtml:
Parameters

The number of entries per page returned. Acceptable range is 3 - 1000.

A token used by the server to indicate the start of the page. Often this is a timestamp or an ID but it is not limited to those. This parameter should not be defined by client applications. The link for the first, last, prev, or next page in the HTTP Link header should define it.

A token used by the server to indicate the end of the page. Often this is a timestamp or an ID but it is not limited to those. This parameter should not be defined by client applications. The link for the first, last, prev, or next page in the HTTP Link header should define it.
filteredMethods.summary: Return the clients network traffic data over time. Usage data is in kilobytes. This endpoint requires detailed traffic analysis to be enabled on the Network-wide > General page. Clients can be identified by a client key or either the MAC or IP depending on whether the network uses Track-by-IP.

name: Inject msg object properties
info:
This sets up the URL path for the form to post its data to.

(within HTML template)
<form class="form-group" method="post" action="/{{url}}" ajax="true">

name: Provision Client Web Form - README
info:
This Flow demonstrates how to create
a simple frontend webpage with Node-RED.

This example creates a form to provision a
Meraki network client.



The public facing page consists of the 
client side JavaScript, CSS and HTML. 

The important technique is how the mustache 
templates are used. Each template will set the
"property" relative to the content. 

The CSS node sets the "msg.payload.style" property.
The JavaScript node sets the "msg.payload.script" property.
The HTML node then includes these properties 
<script>{{{payload.script}}}</script>
<style>{{{payload.style}}}</style>


This example was created by http://www.InternetofLEGO.com
